Aug 27, 2016

A Door of Disappointment Could Lead to a Better Door for 60+ Freelancers

I subscribe to a lot of blogs and email lists, and like many of you, I want to make a difference. The other day, a desktop notification from one of my email subscriptions popped up with the single word “disappointed”. Intrigued, I clicked on the link and found a posting on a job blog for people in the 50+ age bracket, all of whom were frustrated jobseekers. The phenomenon of age discrimination is not new, but the latest crop of boomers and post-boomers are now facing the reality of discrimination first-hand. The barriers to job entry for the older worker is like a steel door slammed in their face and bolted from the inside.

I read further and saw how these workers (these were skilled workers with hard earned pedigrees) were disrespected, patronized, and shut-out from opportunities. It was an eye-opener for many of them, leaving them hopeless.

Fortunately, online communities across the US and Canada hold a premium for entrepreneurial consultants. Our economies are not as reliant on brick and mortar employers to supply all the jobs as they were in the past. Our society has been forced to evolve from the outcomes of the 2008 recession, and the Wall Street and Big Bank Bailouts of the last decade. Those disasters have created opportunities for workers willing to adapt to drastic changes in the job marketplace.

For the out-of-work older worker, many stereo-types, prejudices and attitudes still exist. Most are forced to accept lower paying jobs or take multiple part-time positions. Unfortunately, on the business side, predatory forces are at play. Cave Dwelling employers and Neanderthal Management types have chosen to devalue professional experience in exchange for less experienced younger workers who cost less.

Depending on what KoolAid you’re drinking, the reality is the U.S. full employment numbers are still underneath the pre-2008 employment floor. Hiring managers have learned wages do not have to increase to past levels. After a decade of forcing workers to perform twice the amount of labor for the same wage or face a lay-off, big and small businesses alike learned quickly how to profit under the new paradigm.

Thanks to the PC neutered term “downsizing”, and Obamacare’s “forced” health care coverage for full-time workers, the whole climate of the job market has changed without much blow-back from the media.

But the new paradigm has created millions of opportunities for older workers willing to risk security and start their own businesses.

So What Do You Need to Create a Startup and Become a Successful 60+Entrepreneur?

  1. Passion. To wake up everyday and put forth the energy and hard work to make a living, having a passion for what you do can make all the difference. When you’re doing something you love, it really helps to motivate yourself through the up and downs of business cycles, If find yourself without a passionate drive to push through the tough times, step back and re-think why you don’t have the drive. 
    You must have joy to succeed. Remind yourself it’s important to enjoy the years you have left. If your frustrated because your dream hasn’t manifested yet, that’s OK. It may be a straight forward business problem that can be solved with some sage advice. But if it’s because you really don’t care about what you’re doing everyday, you’ll quickly find yourself hating it like a boring high school class and quickly lose interest.
  2. Enough Money. Yes, you can be successful in a business with little capital, but if you don’t have passion to drive you forward, the lack of funds will force you into the ground. Money can’t solve every problem, but with motivation you’ll do whatever it takes to cut corners, work harder and find a way to make it work. Learn to economize, make every cent count double and only spend money when you need to.
  3. A Plan. SOUNDS obvious, but many people fail at this one point. Calculating any kind of budget on paper is a better than just guessing. I am pretty good at finding way way driving around town or the countryside (like most guys), but many times I have been lost when I don’t have my smartphone. A smartphone with a GPS is like a Plan. A way to get from Point A to Point B. Losing your way financially is a correctable error that need not happen in business. A Plan keeps you aware of how you’re doing money-wise. A Plan will give you indicators when you’ve jumped the tracks financially. The earlier you catch a wrong turn, even with a crude plan in place, the less damage it will do to your business and to your wallet.
  4. Get Advice and Keep Your Friends. True friends are valuable. Do whatever you can to keep them. This includes not going into business with your friends. More lifetime friendships are ruined in business, and more businesses are ruined by friendships. Partnerships with friends are fine when business is great and everyone is in agreement, but when things go sour and money is involved, it gets ugly REALLY fast. This has happened to me several times before I got it through my thick head. It’s Ok to ask for advice from wise friends with a different perspective, but keep them clear of business partnerships. Even the best people get weird when it comes to money. At best when there are disagreements, it will slow the business down, distract you from your mission and make you less agile to solve problems.
  5. Take Care of Yourself. When you were young and staying up all night, playing video games (or whatever), it didn’t hinder you from bouncing back all bright-eyed at 6AM ready for work. Those times are likely gone for you. To succeed you must keep your mind and body in shape. Eat well, sleep properly and exercise to maintain your focus to run the company. Learn what your body is saying to you. Are you tired and sleepy? Are you losing focus and mental acuity? Frustrated? Disciplining yourself to maintain a healthy state will give you the ability to stay sharp mentally and make wise choices. Committing to eating good food, exercising, and sleeping well will pay off with the energy and the mental fortitude to succeed. If you’re like me, you cannot afford to risk what’s at stake.
